Water and Sanitation Program Fiscal Year 2006 Mid-Year Report (MYR) Summary (July 1 ­ December 31, 2005)
1. Introduction
This summary presents the main points and statistics from the Mid-Year Implementation Progress Review of the Water and Sanitation Program (WSP). The MYR includes, in addition to this summary, detailed project-level implementation progress sheets (Annex 1) and new project sheets for new and expanded projects that received additional funding at mid-year (Annex 2). This MYR summary provides an overview of the WSP's key projects, a summary of project delivery status, budget and expenditures, and human resources.
2. Progress on WSP Key Projects
This section presents brief summaries of the largest projects under implementation by each of the WSP regions and headquarters (HQ). These summaries focus on the project objectives, implementation progress, and intermediate outcomes achieved. For further details, please refer to the corresponding project implementation sheets in Annex 1.
WSP-Global: The Domestic Private Sector Participation Initiative (DPSPI): Launched in June 2005, this DFID-funded, 3-year, US$12 million project aims at supporting client countries and multilateral initiatives to leverage greater financial and technical inputs from the domestic private sector. The DPSPI places particular focus on finding ways to unlock the potential of small and medium service providers and to alleviate constraints to accessing market finance for sector development by developing the supply and demand sides of the market and promoting an enabling environment. Since the DPSPI launch, activities have started in 20 projects in 13 countries that include, among others, activities to: (a) explore alternative management models involving domestic in rural areas (Africa) and urban areas (India); (b) improve the capacity of local providers and their legal recognition (Nicaragua, Kenya, Burkina Faso, Cambodia); (c) support regulatory changes that favor pro-poor utility reforms and involvement of the domestic private sector (Benin, Kenya, Burkina Faso, India, Pakistan, Cambodia); (d) encourage sanitation practices and behavioral change and increase demand for private sector services (Cambodia, Vietnam, Niger, Senegal); (e) provide a comprehensive overview of the situation of small-scale providers to develop an understanding of key factors of success (Latin America); (f) develop case studies of successful small-scale providers (Peru, Nicaragua); and (g) improve access to finance of small-scale providers (Kenya, Senegal). Outcomes achieved at this early stage include: (a) pro-poor units are in place in utilities or local governments in Kisumu and Nairobi (Kenya); (b) Goa and (Greater) Bangalore have initiated steps towards creating institutional arrangements for community participation/ grievance redressal, as a first step towards a shift in the power relationships between consumers and providers (public and private); (c) in Cambodia technical training was given to 62 hitherto unlicensed private water supply providers, leading to an increase in applications for licenses.  2 WSP Global: The Public-Private Partnership to Promote Hand washing (PPP-HW)- The PPP- HW works with private soap companies (Unilever, Colgate-Palmolive and Proctor and Gamble), development agencies (World Bank, BNWP, USAID) and research organizations (LSHTM, AED and CDC) to develop handwashing campaigns to reduce the incidence of diarrheal diseases. WSP is the secretariat of the PPP-HW and one of its main implementing partners. Activities implemented in the first half of FY06 included: (a) supporting existing country programs and establishing new ones in additional countries; (b) fund-raising and partnership building; and (c) knowledge sharing and mainstreaming of handwashing programs into projects. During FY06, the handwashing program in Peru was launched where capacity building efforts also continued as well as provision of technical assistance in procurement in Senegal and recruitment of a HW Coordinator for Madagascar. WSP has been successful in raising awareness on the importance of hand washing, resulting in a greater than anticipated demand for support from countries in which programs exist (Peru, Senegal, Madagascar and Ghana) and in establishment of new programs in Colombia, Ecuador, Indonesia, Paraguay, Tanzania and Vietnam. Serious interest has also been expressed in Bolivia, Haiti, Honduras, Nicaragua, Benin, Ethiopia, Nigeria, Uganda, and Bangladesh but WSP does not have the funding to respond to this group of countries. WSP support in awareness-rising is also strengthening existing partnerships with Unilever and USAID for which an agreement for US$450,000 is being finalized. A wide range of other institutions have joined the effort at different stages, for instance the IRC which is in the process of translating the School Sanitation Toolkit (completed last fiscal year) into Spanish and French. The Handwashing Secretariat also played a key role in raising awareness of the importance of hand washing in preventing Avian Flu epidemics. Efforts to mainstream handwashing into projects are also experiencing results, for example in Ecuador where the Handwashing Secretariat is working to incorporate a handwashing component in a $48-million World Bank-funded project that is under preparation.
WP Global: 2006 Development Marketplace (DM) on Water, Sanitation and Energy: WSP and ESMAP (the Energy Sector Management Assistance Program) are the technical partners for this year's DM2006 whose theme is "Innovations for Water, Sanitation and Energy Services to the Poor". The DM looks for innovative solutions from a range of development innovators - civil society groups, social entrepreneurs, private foundations, government agencies, academia, the private sector, and international organizations. Over 2,500 proposals were received from 155 countries (25% from Africa) along four sub-themes: (a) Service Delivery: Sustainable delivery of water supply, sanitation and/or energy services to poor households; (b) Environment: Renewable energy, clean energy technologies, energy efficiency, and/or environmentally sustainable solutions to poor households and to small enterprises; (c) Health: Protecting health from environmental risk factors (indoor air pollution, contaminated drinking water, unsafe sanitation), including innovative programs hygiene promotion and behavioral change; (d) Natural Resources: Sustainable management of natural resources (land, water, forest) specifically for the provision of water supply, sanitation and energy to the poor. A total of 45% of the applications that were submitted relate to water supply and 27% to sanitation. This is a result of the active outreach in WSP's focus countries which attracted a more diverse pool of proposals than in previous years. Fundraising efforts succeeded in raising $4 million out of a target of $6 million.
WSP-Africa: Developing Sanitation Knowledge ­ This four-year, US$1.2 million project aims to develop and disseminate sanitation knowledge across Africa with full programs to be piloted in  3 at least three countries. Under the project, WSP has developed a sanitation marketing framework which includes (a) subsidy policy, (b) learning from the market, (c) over-coming barriers to sanitation demand, and (d) developing the right products and supporting a sanitation industry. The project has also supported networking for knowledge development and sharing through regional and sub-regional conferences (Africasan, Africasan South, East and West/Central) to promote sanitation issues and coordinate responses to sanitation demands. WSP has also provided investment support to Niger, Senegal and Tanzania under which over 60,000 facilities have been constructed and development of condominial system initiated in Senegal. An urban pilot sanitation project has been completed in Niamey (Niger) and lessons learnt are being documented and published. WSP support has contributed to improved access to sanitation products including EcoSan solutions, driven by a better understanding of sanitation drivers. The project is now in a follow-up phase to consolidate and translate the knowledge that has been generated into actions which will mainly include: (a) rolling out sanitation marketing in selected countries; (b) continued and enhanced investment support to Niger, Senegal and Tanzania; and (c) developing sanitation advocacy toolkits to be implemented in the 2-3 countries in which the SanMark program will be rolled out. Other planned key activities include: (a) analytical work on economic and financial aspects of Ecosan, (b) comparative study on SanMark Implementation approaches; and (c) strengthening advocacy and knowledge sharing through regional and sub- regional high-level conferences to raise the profile of sanitation in the policy and cross-country dialogues and lesson sharing. The project has recently received additional funding from SIDA for an expanded phase.
WSP-Africa: MDGs in Africa: This 3-year, US$5.5 million Sida-funded project is now in its final year. The project aims to assist 4 WSP focus countries (Kenya, Tanzania, Burkina Faso and Uganda) meet the MDGs through supporting: (a) development of country owned MDG roadmaps, (b) key regional institutions, (c) sector coordination, and (d) analyses and knowledge sharing on sanitation marketing and Ecosan. During FY06, partnership and coordination mechanisms were started with AMCOW, AFDB and NEPAD. WSP also submitted a proposal to AFDB for setting up a WSP liaison office in Tunis. A partnership office has been established for the AMCOW president and WSP seconded a full time staff member to provide continuous support to AMCOW's work program. WSP has strengthened support to the implementation of this project by opening country offices in Tanzania and Burkina Faso and recruiting senior WSS specialists for Kenya and Uganda. A Water and Sanitation MDG roadmap development toolkit (includes MDG process guide and TORs, financial flows analysis framework, M&E model, coordination guide, reporting format) has been completed. WSS MDG roadmaps have also been completed for all WSP focus countries. In addition, draft Water and Sanitation MDG Country Status Overview (WSS MDG CSO) have been prepared for 20 countries in which stakeholder consultation is ongoing to ensure national ownership and to put in place, capacity and processes for updating the roadmaps and CSOs and for supporting M&E. Key outcomes resulting from this project are that WSS roadmap processes are under implementation in Benin, Burkina Faso, Ghana, Niger, Senegal and Ghana while CSO processes are under implementation for Benin, Burkina, Cape Verde, DRC, Ghana, Mali, Mauritania, Niger and Senegal. The focus for the remaining part of FY06 will be to finalize CSO consultations at country level, organize regional CSO conferences, organize training and capacity building for participating countries, and develop M&E systems.  4 WSP-East Asia: Water Supply and Sanitation Policy and Action Planning (WASPOLA II) in Indonesia- The goal of this four-year, US$6.2 million phase of the project is to support the Government of Indonesia (GOI) adopt, implement and monitor a comprehensive water and sanitation sector policy framework encompassing both community- and institutionally-managed services. During the review period, WSP supported GOI to increase efforts in policy implementation and broadening the policy framework to incorporate institutionally managed services by: (a) operationalizing the national policy at district level, (b) preparing national strategies and local actions to achieve the MDGs, (c) carrying out field trials to generate knowledge on options for delivering WSS services at affordable costs, (d) increasing capacity implementation of institutionally managed WSS services, and (e) increasing emphasis on environmental sanitation. Field trials in Community-Led Total Sanitation (CLTS) have been completed, results disseminated and stakeholder consensus built through workshops involving national and local government and NGOs; field trials in 6 district-level governments; and rapid expansion over a few months from the first few communities to about 30 by end 2005. Other outcomes include: (a) Guidelines and Tools for Policy implementation and scale up to achieve local MDG targets completed and endorsed and are now being disseminated by local governments (LGs); (b) Financing strategy for LGs to achieve the MDGs and operationalize sector policy completed; (c) Training of national and district teams completed to disseminate and build capacity and dialogue on the new policy. The focus over the remaining period will be to develop an M&E strategy, continued dissemination of the national policy and incorporation of lessons from field trials into a national sanitation and hygiene strategy.
WSP-East Asia: Indonesia Sanitation Sector Development Project (ISSDP): This is a new 3-year, US$7 million component of a $22 million Dutch-funded project under which WSP will assist the Government of Indonesia (GOI) develop an enabling environment to stimulate investments and improve services in sanitation through strengthened policy framework, strategies, regulation, institutions and building capacity of all key national and local institutions mandated. Under the project, WSP will: (a) assist in building awareness on the need for improved sanitation and capacity of key stakeholders; (b) elaborate a comprehensive sanitation policy and regulatory framework, (c) test the financing, technical, poverty and capacity building strategies to operationalize the policy, and (d) clarify the institutional framework for sanitation at national, provincial and local levels.. WSP support has contributed to the formation of GOI Sanitation Working Group to coordinate ministries and resources for sanitation development. It has also initiated an important study The State of Sanitation in Indonesia: the Cost of Doing Nothing to raise awareness on the dire state of sanitation and mobilize the support and resources needed. Good collaboration has been established with donors such as the World Bank, Ausaid, SIDA, ADB, USAID that are active in the sanitation field and a good foundation for implementing the project had been laid, with strong leadership from the planning agency (BAPPENAS). WSP will continue to support development of an enabling investment framework for sanitation, create sanitation demand and build the capacity of key agencies such as LGs and water utilities (PDAMs), in the implementation of the sanitation policy including strategies for providing sanitation to poor urban communities. The project is in its first year where the focus has been on relationship and foundation-building and mobilization of needed resources to ensure successful implementation.  5 WSP-Latin America: Strengthening WSS services in small towns: The objective of this 3-year, US$4 million project is to develop new water supply and sanitation management models in 10 small towns, using a public-private-social approach. The implementation of this project is in its third year, and it is currently focusing on: (a) improving local government capacity to monitor service quality, (b) finalizing and validating management models, (c) developing sector information systems, and (d) conducting studies to evaluate users' payment capacity and supporting three municipalities in service rehabilitation. The socio-economic studies in three municipalities, the preparation of sector assessment, and the development of intervention guidelines are under way. The focus for the rest of the fiscal year will be to finalize the process of contracting specialized operators for the small towns, disseminate and replicate lessons learnt at national level and incorporate them into government policy, and finally, to develop a sector information system.
WSP-South Asia: Utility/City Level Reforms: WSP had been a driving force in the Delhi Jal Board (DJB) reform program, a 4-year, US$1.5m. project to improve WSS services in Delhi, one of the largest utilities in the world, by re-introducing 24/7 water supply, focusing on management, robust communications and interactions with parliamentarians. The key activity planned for FY06 was the development of institutional, regulatory and technical options for reforms in Delhi though preparation of a performance agreement with Delhi government, and an incremental approach to partnerships with the private sector. This activity, the key one under this project for this FISCAL YEAR, has been put on hold pending a review of the partnership with the private sector as the approach to improving services in Delhi and determination of a way forward by the government. In the meantime, however, WSP has completed a demand assessment study and is continuing to support mechanisms for reaching the poor and to advocate for reforms that will ensure 24/7 services to users.
WSP-All regions: The Global Practice Teams (GPTs): In an initiative to strengthen global learning and knowledge management, WSP established GPTs, which are virtual teams of experts in a given subject area/topic that are: (a) taking the lead in generating knowledge in specific thematic areas, (b) ensuring quality enhancement of WSP products, and (c) the main thematic interlocutors with the World Bank and other IFIs and donor agencies. Five GPTs on strategic communications for Reform, Finance, Rural Water, Sanitation and Hygiene, and Urban Poor and Domestic Private Sector were established and are in the process of implementing their work programs. GPT projects include activities to: (a) enhance WSP's capacity to support strategic communication initiatives of institutions in client and other countries (Communications GPT); (b) improve public financial management practices in the use of WSS relater public/donor resources by stakeholders and leverage additional local/domestic resources for WSS (Finance GPT); (c) develop and implement a global strategy of communication and dissemination for sanitation and hygiene knowledge resources (Sanitation and Hygiene GPT); (d) develop improved management models for RWSS and carry out analytical work on productive use of water and the link with poverty reduction (Rural GPT); and (e) help utilities to develop and implement roadmaps for institutional reforms including options for increasing access to the poor (Urban GPT). The activities of the urban GPT are closely linked to many of the DPSPI activities. The GPTs have successfully built their cross-regional teams and launched many of the activities in their work plans. They are also building vital linkages with the World Bank through the various Thematic Groups and with other partners as well as identifying national/regional/global  6 fora in which they can share and disseminate their work. WSP will continue to maintain a balance between country and regional/global activities to ensure that the focus remains at country level where new knowledge generated by the GPTs is expected to enhance our clients' efforts at increasing access to sustainable WSS.
3. Delivery Status
One of the main objectives of the Mid-Year Review is to identify projects: (i) that are delayed and require corrective measures, (ii) whose scope of work requires modification, and (iii) that can be expanded based on additional funding received during the first half of the fiscal year or through budget re-allocations. The mid-year review focuses not only on the project outputs, but also on progress towards achievement of intermediate milestones in an effort to improve monitoring and documentation of project impacts.
The MYR analysis indicates that 65% of the 114 projects were progressing well on target. Only 2% of the projects were dropped due to difficulties with implementation. For purposes of the MYR, projects are defined to be delayed if the delivery of their intermediate outputs is delayed by more than two months and this delay may jeopardize on-time delivery of FY06 outputs. The MYR has given an opportunity to WSP management to review the reasons for project delays. In order of importance, these reasons include:
a) Difficulties with trust fund set up, project accounts, and hiring of personnel were underestimated by task managers who were used to plan outputs for projects already under implementation. While these delays are normal, the original project plans were too optimistic for a large number of projects initiated in FY06; b) Change in focus/topics (e.g. the Delhi Jal Board in India) and government processes that contributed to delays for 12 projects, mainly affecting South Asia and East Asia; c) Staff changes especially Task Managers that contributed to delays for 8 projects, particularly affecting East Asia and South Asia regions; d) Complex procurement processes and deficiencies in procurement processes contributed to delays for 7 projects; and e) Delayed funding and receipt of donor contribustions, that contributed to delays for 4 projects and mainly affected South Asia and East Asia.
As part of the MYR, task managers, regional team leaders, and the program manager have identified actions to accelerate implementation progress to improve the delivery status of the delayed projects. Several measures have been already implemented, including: (i) completion of a comprehensive human resources hiring program; (ii) establishment of a procurement systems task force and implementation of recommendations; (iii) hiring of a global administration coordinator and senior resource management officer; and (iv) realism analysis of project sheets. In addition, WSP management will take the following actions to strengthen business planning and implementation:
· finalize the revision of the HR plan to more adequately respond to an expanding program; · staff training to strengthen procurement planning and to streamline the business planning process; and  7 · develop a system for more rigorous quality review of projects at entry in particular to ensure realism in new projects.

7. Fund Raising Activities
Since the FY05 End-year Report, two agreements are now under preparation for the East Asia Region with SIDA: one for Sustainable Sanitation in East Asia (SUSEA) targeted to Indonesia and the Philippines (estimated US$ 8.03 million over 4 years), and the other for sanitation and water for the Mekong region (estimated US$ 4.45 million over 2 ½ years), in partnership with the Stockholm Environment Institute and International Development Enterprises (in an effort to implement the WSP Funding Strategy reviewed and endorsed by the WSP Council in its 2005 meeting). The Mekong region program is planned to be established as a multidonor trust fund, kicking off this new mechanism proposed at the last WSP Council meeting in 2005.
There have been advances on a number of other fronts as well in the area of fund-raising. The Gates Foundation has indicated strong interest in providing US$ 1.2 million to support the Development Marketplace competitive grant program for 2006, and an agreement is being drawn up. Advanced discussions are also underway with other potential new funding partners, including Google Foundation for the Development Marketplace and USAID for the Global Handwashing Partnership.

The first indicator, which read "total funding commitments" in the Funding Strategy document, has been restated as "total funds available" to the program for the current fiscal year and beyond. This precision facilitates comparable data collection going forward. Funds are considered available to the program on the basis of cash on hand at the start of a fiscal year plus receipts expected on formally signed agreements at the prevailing US dollar rates of exchange.
"Untied Core funding" has been defined to include funds without specific restrictions to support the overall work program of WSP but excludes funds specified to a subset of countries within a region or specific themes or activities.
The difference in total funds available in the last six-month period relates to the signing of new multi-year agreements with France (Agence Francaise de Développement, a new partner for WSP), Sweden (Swedish International Development Cooperation Agency - SIDA) and Switzerland (Swiss Agency for Development Corporation), although these funds had already been agreed in principle at the time of the last Council.
8. Human Resources
In order to implement effectively the expanded program of activities, the human resources of WSP are increasing. WSP decided to coordinate its recruitment efforts with the World Bank for a comprehensive search across regions. WSP and the World Bank have joined forces to share costs and increase the reach of the announcement, particularly to developing countries. The job vacancy announcements were posted in the World Bank's intranet, the Economist, Jeune Africa, East Africa, Wall Street Jounal ­ ASia InfoBae (Argentina), Reforma (Mexico) and the Gazeta Mercantil (Brazil). Information about the cluster requirement was also circulated in a number of internet magazines and e-newsletters. In addition, all members of the World Bank's Water Sector were notified about the ongoing exercise and were asked to inform their peers about the pipeline building effort in the World Bank.
At the moment, WSP has 40 GE+ (professional level) staff members and 41 extended term consultants (ETCs). These two categories are part of the full-time staff working in WSP projects. They are complemented by a team of administrative staff and highly specialized short-term consultants. In the first six months of the FY06, 5 staff/ETCs departed and 22 have been hired.
